newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Future HK govt inherits delicate property problem.
newsitem.headline: Future HK govt inherits delicate property problem.

text.p: Cooling Hong Kong's soaring property sector has become a future government's first policy test and the decisions made could signal the direction of Hong Kong's economy under new rule.

In essence, Beijing-backed Tung Chee-hwa's Special Administrative Region (SAR) government must stop a "bubble" build up before it bursts with disastrous results for Hong Kong's property-driven economy. The challenge is how to do this without dampening real estate prices too much, a development that could lead to an economic downturn.
"I think the new government is between a rock and a hard place," said Michael Green, property analyst at Salomon Brothers.
Tung Chee-hwa and his chief property advisor C.Y. Leung inherit a colony with a critical shortage of physical property supplies, chased by a growing population.
"If liquidity keeps coming to the residential market, (you'll have a) situation where more and more money is chasing a relatively static stock of residences," Green said.
"It's not sustainable at all, there is the potential of a bubble developing and bursting," Green said.
Franklin Lam, property analyst at Goldman Sachs agreed.
Lam said the Hong Kong property market was like opium, sucking in capital addictively and weakening other sectors.

"When economies mature, you have a diversification of earning sectors. In Hong Kong, in the last 10 years it's gone the other way and we are increasingly courting only one sector--the property sector," he said.
Over the past 18 months, property prices have risen 65 percent, while wages have risen by a paltry eight percent and rents by five percent.
"People are still arguing it's not bubble, but I think it's very very frothy," Lam said.
Green said property bubble bursts were undesireable and often involved the government bailing out an entire industry at the expense of the tax-paying public.
There are two camps equally ardent about what the government should do, possibly as soon as it is sworn in on July 1.
"We believe C.Y. Leung and the new government may have little choice other than to introduce a residential speculation tax," Salomon Brothers' Green said.
But Hong Kong's freewheeling, laissez-faire economy naturally shies away from taxes of any kind.

"If Hong Kong introduces a sales tax or a capital gains tax, the first effect will be on the property market and prices may drop 10-15 percent," said Hong Kong Property Services (Agency) managing director Michael Choi Ngai-min.
If prices dropped too fast, the rest of the economy could be affected, he said, noting that 40 percent of the stock market was related to property.

"C.Y. Leung is not the kind of person that would want to advocate dramatic interferance in the free market. What he is more likely to look at is increasing supply," Martin Tacon, senior associate at CS First Boston said recently.
Hong Kong's property tycoons agree.
"(The new government) should announce a firm resolve to release a massive amount of land into the market," said Ronnie Chan, chairman of Hang Lung Development Co Ltd and Amoy Properties Ltd.
"The only way to solve (property prices jerking up and down) is to have a steady stream of supply," he told reporters at the Foreign Correspondents' Club.
